discourse_list.title: Progress Update on the legal structure for Centrifuge RWA vaults

content.content: The first real world asset went live on Maker almost a year ago. The first DAI backed by RWA was minted by New Silver in April 2021. Since then we have been continuously improving the technology and the legal structure. We continue to work with the RWF Core Unit (thanks to @christiancdpetersen and @eumenes!) on structures both for US based issuers like the ones live today as well as an off-shore structure based in Jersey. In this post we want to share progress on the legal structure for US-based assets. The Jersey structure is a collaboration with RWF Core Unit and Nebula Capital, a MIP6 application we are very excited about. We will introduce it in a later post. In this update we explain the basic principles of how we expect that this structure will work in the future. This structure will provide formalization for our pool transactions. This upgrade is intended to better protect the interest of investors and the DAO. The two key changes to highlight are:   We are proposing that issuers will appoint a third party trustee to act on behalf of the DAO and other investors. The trustee will be able to protect the interests of the DAO and ensure independent control of the assets. It would also handle distributions in case of default leaving it no longer in control of the issuer or a liquidator. We are in initial discussions with some potential trustees.   The second proposed change is the introduction of a lock-box. A lock-box is a term of art meaning a segregated account for assets held outside the control of the issuer and the SPV. This structure means that the SPV assets are no longer in control of the issuer but in control of the trustee. It will be the role of the trustee to receive and handle payments to and from the lock-box and make sure the right parties (for example Maker) receive the payments. This means the issuer doesn’t control the funds from the borrowers to the Maker vault, reducing the risk of loss of funds or misuse of funds by the issuer.   This setup is intended to better protect investors and issuers from potential litigation claims and provides a consistent and coherent story for discussions with regulators and third party service providers such as custodians and banks. This type of structure is well established in the industry and accepted by many TradFi players. Using this structure should make it easier to bring TradFi players into DeFi which will expand the types and quantity of real world assets available to Maker, which we think is a key step to reducing the volatility of DAI. The schematic shared below (thanks to @christiancdpetersen) is a work in progress with the RWF Core Unit with support provided by Shearman & Sterling as engaged by the RWF CU as counsel, along with Manatt as Centrifuge’s counsel.  Credit to @christiancdpetersen Some of the different pieces in the diagram to highlight are:  The lock-box arrangement ringfences the payments so these are not subject to the possible insolvency of the SPV. The use of a trustee better protects the interests of the investors and provides recourse in case of default. The pledges in favor of the trustee remove bankruptcy risk with respect to the underlying assets.  We remain committed to coming up with a robust legal structure to ensure that the DAO’s interests are protected while growing the presence of diversified RWA as collateral. Please join us next week on Wednesday February 23 5pm UTC at our community AMA call where we will share more about the legal update, and why on-chain securitization matters with other members of the Centrifuge team. We look forward to your participation and questions, and meeting all of you!
Thank you for this detailed update. Perhaps this is a silly question. Why does maker not directly hold the tokens instead of by “trusted legal entity” Thank you
I think @christiancdpetersen would be a better resource for the structuring of the Maker vault. I expect it is due to the decentralized nature of the DAO.

A really good question. As a practical matter, the DROP Token will be effectively locked into the Maker vault in order to generate DAI. The original Centrifuge model (and this update) contemplates that DROP and TIN Tokenholders will execute a subscription agreement for acquisition of the tokens. We added the layer of the indenture plus trustee to ensure that there was an independent third party in the real world that could take instructions from the DROP and TIN token holders as and when required under the indenture. Both the subscription agreement and the indenture plus trustee layer required a trusted legal entity (8). For purposes of the subscription agreement and the indenture, the trusted legal entity (8) will be the DROP Token holder. As a practical matter, however, the DROP Token will be deposited in the Maker vault. I hope this helps. Please let me know if you have any doubts. This is an iterative process, so questions are welcomed as we continually refine the implementation.

christiancdpetersen:  an independent third party in the real world that could take instructions from the DROP and TIN token holders as and when required under the indenture.   If it is not complicated, may you speak about how instructions occur? Are they fixed options or can be anything? Do they communicate back? To who? Thank you
Thank you for this update team, looking forward to the AMA.

Appreciate this additional color. Does this new approach address auctions?  In particular, will a broker/dealer or some other regulated entity be used to auction off the debt securities (DROP tokens)? Having looked closely at the Centrifuge model previously, I recall the lack of broker/dealer involvement was a concern (and still may be given the active involvement of SEC enforcement in our industry at the moment). If there is no broker/dealer involved on the auctions, can you or your counsel from Sherman explain why not? All of my questions above assume that there is no effort to block US-based IPs from participating in DROP auctions. Thanks. Tosh

Hi Tosh, It is a good question. We don’t plan on any auction process. These are permissioned pools and open only to Accredited Investors under Reg D. As these are exempt offers under the '33 Act, there is no need for involvement of a broker-dealer. We may look into future plans for US retail offers where we would need to involve a broker-dealer, but that is not in the current planning.

Thanks for the input. Much appreciated. But just so I understand,  and as I may not have been clear earlier, in the case of the underlying asset going under water, DROP tokens would not be available to purchase through a collateral auction? In other words, there’s no need for a BD because the DROP would never be available for flips? @elidco

DROP tokens would not be available to purchase through a collateral auction? In other words, there’s no need for a BD because the DROP would never be available for flips?  You are correct. For now there are no flips for DROP so this is not a problem. While I would love to see a future of liquid secondary markets for RWAs that are on Centrifuge this is not the reality yet today. This structure does not liquidate tokens by auctioning them off on chain but instead off chain payments from the borrowers are used to repay Maker if it wanted to “liquidate” the vault. This is also how all other RWA vaults under consideration from Maker are structured. In the long term if we see secondary markets of RWA backed tokens by Centrifuge then I think we would have to revisit your question.

We have not yet finalized the draft indenture. However, I would envision that the instructions (if and when required) will be a combination of traditional finance (for the TIN) and DeFi for the DROP (assuming that all the DROP tokens are deposited into a Maker vault). If DROP tokens are distributed between a Maker vault and other persons, the instructions for DROP may include both a traditional finance and a DeFi approach. I did not understand the reference to “fixed options”, so please excuse me if I have not clearly responded to your question.

That is correct. In the case the assets are underwater, there might be an auction of the RWA held by the SPV and pledged to the trustee. The proceeds of such sale could then be made to DROP tokenholders after conversion into Dai. But the trustee would not auction the tokens themselves as these are not transferable.

Would the lockbox be a DACA or a springing DACA?     christiancdpetersen:  We added the layer of the indenture plus trustee to ensure that there was an independent third party in the real world that could take instructions from the DROP and TIN token holders as and when required under the indenture   This makes me think that it is a DACA, and that DROP and TIN holders would have some sort of borrowing base certificate to confirm distributions on a regular basis before any cash is released back to the Asset Originator. Though I could also see some language in that indenture to allow for a springing DACA. I think the difference is key - a standard DACA could result in some cash flow management challenges on the Asset Originator, depending on how frequently the borrowing base is reviewed and lockbox cash is released.

While the details of the collateral arrangements will only be worked out with a specific issuer and specific trustee, my expectation is that the lockbox would be exclusively controlled by the trustee meaning that there is no need for a DACA.

Thank you for all Centrifuge participants in the AMA. It’s been a long road to reset the legal structure to market standards. The quality of the conversations held today and to get up to this point are a good sign that our ecosystem is finally maturing. Thanks to all the Centrifuge team for your efforts to date. We look forward to re-start engagements in the next phase of your evolution. On behalf of the rwf team, Will

Hi, hoping someone can help clarify the structure described in the schematic, specifically relating to the DROP and TIN tokens. Do the DROP and TIN tokens represent the total financed amount ie the DAI loan? What is the distinction between the two tokens?

Hi Francis. Yes, the DROP and TIN represent the full amount of the DAI financing.The DROP tokens are the senior tranche and the TIN tokens are the junior tranche. From a MakerDAO perspective, the vault will be 100% DROP.

Thanks for the kind words and continued partnership! The engagement on the call yesterday was invigorating and barring the audio difficulties, hopefully helped to clarify questions that the community had. We look forward to getting the current WIP legal structure to the finish line together.
Ok thanks, so this would be akin to notes issued by a CLO?
Yes, the structure of the legal documentation will be similar to a CLO
